_description: ‘The X Commaundments of love’ — fourteen stanzas rhyme royal including Envoy

BodFair16.First Lines:
Certes ferre extendeth yet my reasonThis mater as yet should be to
                    discryue…
BodFair16.Last Lines:
…For true seruice him to auanceAnd call him into your
                    remembrance
BodFair16.Note: Added by a hand of the 17th century.
BodFair16.Attributed Title:
The x Commaundements of Love (f. 184); Explicit the x commandements of Love
                    (f. 185v)
BodFair16.Facsimiles:
Norton-Smith,  John. 
             “Introduction.” 
             Bodleian Library MS Fairfax 16.
         London: Scolar Press, 1979.

CamTCC599.First Lines:
Certes fer extendeth yet my ResonThys mater as yet shuld be to
                    discryueBut trust youre grace wyll in thys seasonConsider how with
                    connyng that I scryue…
CamTCC599.Last Lines:
…ffor tru seruice hym to AuaunceAnd call hym in to your
                    Remembraunce
CamTCC599.Attributed Author: by Chaucer (added by later hand, f. 109)
CamTCC599.Attributed Title:
The x Commaundementes of loue (f. 109); Explicit the x Commaundmentes of
                    loue (f. 110)

         Norman, OK: Pilgrim, 1987.
